review: A comprehensive documentary that combines a great amount of video and audio footage with gorgeous animation and interviews to create a profoundly revealing character study, even if the final result feels a bit too long and some things are left hanging - like, where is Dave Grohl?

I often treat it as a moment of embarrassment that Kurt Cobain remains such a symbol of my Generation. A brilliant musician and a terribly strange messed up human being. Despite its subject, the documentary is one of most well crafted that I have seen in ages.
A fascinating chronicle of a troubled music icon.

Brett Morgen (The Kid Stays In The Picture) uses archival footage, notes, drawings, and unseen home videos to bring to light the life and times of Kurt Cobain, the legendary singer/guitarist for the band Nirvana. We get a very intimate glimpse of the beloved musician from his early years all the way up to 1994, when he tragically took his own life at the age of 27. Having seen other documentaries produced on Nirvana and Cobain, I couldn't help feel that they were more idol-worship and spent less time focusing on the troubled life this man had. So, I was surprised and in some cases shocked with how much of his past they discussed. The use of home video footage to show how drug addiction drastically changed his mental and physical state, it was extremely upsetting to see. I grew up listening to these guys! Kurt was a gifted songwriter and musician. So, to get this level of intimacy and detail about his life. To see the events that made him the way he was. It was impressive that someone was able to put a documentary together that felt less like a love letter and more of a character study. I think it is the only real way you can effectively tell this story and they did it very well. On top of all this! Morgen utilized the incredible animation skills of Stefan Nadelman and Hisko Hulsing, to bring to life drawings done by Kurt. As well as, brilliantly bringing to life major events in the young Cobain's life. Which included his family troubles and his musical beginnings. The only issue I really had with the film was the exclusion of Dave Grohl, whose omission was a choice the director made. I felt it would have given the film a little more. But, ultimately I had no major issues with this documentary. It is very well done! The animated sequences alone make this worth your time. Even if you don't like Kurt Cobain! This is a great character study that doesn't pull any punches as it focuses on the events that both made and ultimately destroyed an extremely talented musician.
In a strange twisted vision to tell the story most music fans know, I think Cobain if still around would approve of the technique used by this film to tell his story.

Morgan builds his story from home movies, artwork, artifacts of all sorts culled from the vaults and the personal collections of family members, including long-lost audiotapes, which are illustrated with dreamlike animations. It's a heckuva way to tell the story.
Truly a sad look at an icon. You can't come away from watching it without thinking what a messed up, confused man, but above all think about what could have been.

Don't take the title lightly. Out of the many flavors of Cobain docs, this is the most pivotal as it explores the dark worlds of depression, addiction, anxiety, and fame. Morgen's melding of Cobain's journals and art traps us in the mind of a generation's savior - a savior that that generation never understood.

I will start off by saying, you don't have to be a huge Nirvana fan to appreciate this documentary. I for one am a fan of NIrvana and Kurt Cobain, not a fanatic like some people who grew up in the 90s, but I did enjoy their music. Personally I am more of a metal fan loving bands like Pantera, Kreator, and Slayer. I always respected Nirvana, because even though their music was pretty simple and most of the songs just use the same chords and a lot of distortion, they helped rid the universe of moronic "hair metal" and "glam metal" bands. Bands like Poison and Warrant with their cheesy rock ballads in the 80s were so ready to be gone, they just needed a little push, and Nirvana gave them that push. And behind Nirvana came good bands like Pearl Jam, Smashing Pumpkins, Stone Temple Pilots etc... It was kind of an explosion of everything anti-hair metal. No longer was it clubs on the sunset strip with bands dressing up like women and fans of those bands also dressing up like women, wearing lipstick and putting a lot of hairspray in their hair, honestly it was disgraceful and one of the worst trends that music ever went through in my opinion. So to see it be destroyed by Nirvana and Kurt Cobain was a beautiful thing to me. It was now dress however you want, and let out all the aggression you have inside your body. But on to the documentary. Music documentaries are really hit or miss, it is rare that you are going to see a music documentary that you will enjoy if you are not a fan of the subject the movie is about. VH1's Behind The Music series was pretty good for a little bit when it first started out, doing short mini documentaries on musicians, but even now they are horrible. I saw a Behind the Music on the likes of 50 Cent, Pink and Neyo. Music acts that haven't really even been out that long at all, surely not long enough to warrant a Behind The Music. Just seems rather stupid to me. But Montage of Heck you can enjoy without being a fan of Kurt Cobain. This isn't only a film about the man in Nirvana, but also a pretty strong showing of what drugs will do to you. It does not matter how rich or famous you are, if you are a drug addict, you are equal to everyone else that is a drug addict as well. Being someone who has struggled with addiction in the past, I felt really connected with Kurt Cobain in this documentary. I know some people will say it was almost a little too much to watch him just crumble in front of your eyes as the movie progresses, but guess what, people need to see stuff like this. For too long has the world kind of hid their eyes from drug addiction. Just thinking it is a bunch of losers and down and out junkies who do nothing for society. When in reality, people of all races, sex, class, religion, rich, poor etc are affected by this. This is a great documentary that really takes you truly behind the scenes at one of the more mysterious figures in music. Yes, he is beloved to this day after committing suicide. But its amazing to watch a guy who pretty much had everything he could ever ask for. A family, money, fame, anything he could ever imagine, and he was just flat out miserable regardless of all of it, mostly do to his long time heroin addiction. I don't think Cobain is a musical genius by any means, but he's a polarizing personality and an innovative musician nonetheless. I just wish he would have truly committed to getting the help he needed because its clear as day that he was crying for help.

A unique music documentary that even casual Nirvana fans should enjoy. The animated sequences were pretty cool. And the music was spot-on for once, as these kind of movies often don't end up using applicable songs. I am mostly out of the grunge phase in my life and would have enjoyed this more in my teen years, but it was nice to revisit an old interest. (First and only viewing - 5/16/2015)
Really good documentary. This showed his whole life along with audio tapes of him and video footage and diary entries. You start to understand a little more about why he was the way he was.

Whether you like his music or not, this documentary is a fascinating look into a man who, for the most part, was a troubled genius. The super 8 films and home videos of Kurt and Courtney are what make the film standout. I thought the interviews were insightful, but didn't need the dramatic lighting and camera angles. It is less about his music than it is trying to figure out what was going through his mind and made him what he was.Grade: B+
Absolutely brilliant and moving, #kurtcobain:montageofheck is a uniquely artistic and fitting documentary of one of the most iconic artists of a generation.

Sure it doesn't delve into the music side of things as much as it arguably should. But both as a glimpse into the headspace of a tortured artist and as an avant garde narrative, it is a stunningly effective journey.

Brett Morgen writes and directs Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck. The film focuses on the life of Kurt Cobain, and does not venture much into the aspects of Nirvana. The film starts off with footage of his childhood as well as interviews from his family. Its clear that his troubled teen years led to much of the angst present in his music. The film somewhat loses the documentary sense and becomes more of a myriad of imagery, and splicing together montages to construct what may have been going though his life. Footage of his wife Love also ensues, and the focus of the film really shifts to that relationship. Those looking for more a music based documentary will be disappointed as this film really only mentions the albums being made in passing. The film does not attempt at all to look at the impact or legacy of his life past his death. Overall Montage of Heck is worth watching for any Kurt Cobain or Nirvana fan, but I felt the film had a bit more fluff with the imagery and montage aspects as an artistic film rather than a documentary.

Incredibly self-indulgent, but I guess it has to be, right? Seemed a bit long to me. Very fair portrayal, though probably too heavy-handed at some points. Could have used more Dave Grohl. I heard that the director didn't have time-MAKE TIME, dude. He's the most famous/successful out of all of the people who knew Kurt.
I listen to nirvana nearly everyday and if your to watch any doc. about kurt and nirvana it should be this one, drunk then sober.
A compelling and refreshing take into the life of one of the biggest stars of the 90's, Montage of Heck is a mesmerizing, stylish and intimate portrait of the beloved rock star.
you gotta live long enough to learn how to live.

My first memory of Nirvana was in early April, 1994. I was ten years old. I was at school and we had 'library time' with the kids in my class and class above ours. I came in and saw a group of kids sitting around one of those big, grey, rectangular tape decks with a pair of coil corded, oversized black headphones attached. They were all squeezed together listening to a tape one of them brought in. I came over and asked what was up. One of the older kids handed me the headphones and said 'this guy just blew his head off' (kids are great at exaggerating to induce shock effect). I put the headphones on and 'Smells Like Teen Spirit' was blaring out of them. I had never heard of Nirvana before, never heard the song before, but two seconds in I was hooked. As I grew older and became more educated on the whole Cobain legend, my fascination with this band, and this person in particular, was one of both awe, that someone could be so talented and write songs that were so good, and dark fascination at this person's train wreck of a life. And I wasn't alone. During his life, Cobain was a fascinating figure, for all the right and wrong reasons, and in his death, his legend firmly embedded in the annuls of rock and roll history, his dichotomy laden and troubled personality is part of one of the most interesting stories in popular music. Although there have been a number of doc's on Cobain and Nirvana and their music, Montage of Heck is the first 'authorized' examination of Cobain's life on film. This means his family has allowed maverick documentarian Brett Morgan total access to the Cobain archives, so to speak. And this film is chock full of audio clips, musical sound bites, televised interviews and home videos which attempt to bare all of Cobain in an attempt to better understand him. And it works, for the most part. His mother had the great foresight to compile hours upon hours of home videos of him from birth to stardom. His wife took over where his mother left off, compiling hours upon hours of home videos of him in the thick of his stardom. These are the most disturbing aspect of the film. More so than the twisted drawings and manic depressive ramblings in his notebooks, the wall of horror movie sound collages he compiled on tape recorders and the smear campaign of media reports that attempted to show the world he and his wife were little more than self destructive junkies, it's the home videos that create the biggest impact. Such as an impossibly skinny Kurt doting on his daughter, playing with her and making her laugh and lavishing love on her. And in another scene a few minutes later nodding out in a heroin daze with her on his lap while Courtney Love attempts to give her her first haircut, while admonishing him for being high in front of his daughter. You see, in these sad clips and the interviews he was doing and the skyrocketing success of the band and the exaggerated reports in the media, a man deteriorating in front of your eyes. It's difficult to watch. As we're led through Cobain's short life, a small group of people connected to him throughout give interviews. This includes his mother, his wife, his sister, an old girlfriend (the one he famously wrote 'About A Girl' for), his semi-estranged father and Krist Novaselic. There is no Dave Grohl. Some people have wondered about this and assumed, as the doc was done with the complete support and cooperation of Courtney Love, that Grohl didn't participate due to his (to say the least) difficult relationship with her over the years. In actuality, the reasoning is much less high school drama than that. This is a documentary about Cobain, not Nirvana, and Morgan wanted it to be a personal one with a small group of participants. And Novaselic was there with him from the beginning. So only one former Nirvana member was needed. Also, Grohl was apparently in the middle of a new Foo Fighters album and his own subsequent HBO doc so didn't initially have the time. That's about it. He did eventually give an interview which will probably end up as a bonus feature on the DVD/Blu-Ray release. Because there's a lot of audio and music clips in the film, Morgan had a talented team of animators come in to supplement it with a series of animations. They're well done and interesting, but also a little cheesy. What works much better is Morgan taking Kurt's doodles and comic strips and lyrics and journal entries and animating them to supplement the music and dialogue. It looks very cool and is very effective. I don't know that I would call Montage of Heck, as some people have, the best or most intimate rock bio ever. There are better ones. I would say though that it offers the most complete picture of who this complicated person was, warts and all. It doesn't give him a God complex or idolize him or present him as an avenging hero. If anything it's a good deterrent for people to stay the fuck away from heroin (as if they needed another) and to pity the people he left behind. It also makes you wonder why those around him didn't do more when he was so obviously self destructing before their eyes. As Novaselic says early in the film, with 20/20 hindsight, the warnings were all there for anyone to see. In his journals, in his drawings, in his demeanour, and most certainly in his songs. But too late is too late. A modern rock greek tragedy if there ever was one.

Hailed as the documentary that would give you the full story of Cobain's life, it's no surprise Montage of Heck not only cant quite deliver, it appears to be missing some essential moments and points of view, I wonder who's fault that could be... For those of you, and I cant believe I'm typing this, who arent aware of Kurt Cobain and his troubled past, his legacy and indeed the impact he had on a generation, Cobain managed to give the youth of the 90's a voice, his monolithic band Nirvana, broke boundries and walls to allow a sense of purpose and importance to a younger generation, who up until that point struggled with growing up, being socially accepted and having a voice. All this came at a price however, when the confines of his dark mind forced him to turn to heroin abuse, which resulted in the man taking his live. Oh and then there is all that Courtney Love conspiracy... Montage of Heck does manage to get some critical moments right, it characterizes Cobain perfectly through video, audio recordings, diary scribbles, art work and indeed a cartoonish style immalgimation of all of the above. It gives a heart gushingly real insight into Cobain, the man behind the ice cool exterior and it just about manages to make his legacy all the more appealing to a new generation. Where it drops the ball however, is not having quite enough contributors, most likely due to the tired nature of exposing Cobain's problems and having a second act that is clearly tampered with , steering the focus away from Cobain and more onto his equally troubled wife, Courtney Love. It's been reported that Love forced film makers to remove footage, how much of that was detrimental or indeed incriminating to whoever, we will never know, but the film clearly loses focus and trajectory the moment she steps into the frame, killing off any form of acceptable resolution. What ever you view points may be on the woman, she is every bit as important to Cobain's story as Nirvana, so her inclusion is needed, but documentaries need to sit on the fence, not be threatened by outside sources. There is a wonderful film in here somewhere, but it struggles with some basic premises that most other documentaries thrive upon. Watchable.

It doesn't close any cases as far as his untimely death goes but it sheds some light on his life from the faces of many of the people who were closest to him.
Other than the unnecessary Courtney Love nudity this was very entertaining and well done.

Stunning animations and editing tricks weave together a story of a disturbed beautiful mind. It's a bag of emotions, intimate life moments captured on VHS and riveting performances with little narration.
Very interesting. But it revived suicidal thoughts in me...

I'm truly surprised with these 97%. It's highly produced set of family movies... and like all family movies, they are boring. And for periods that they didn't have a family movie it looks like they made stuff up. I can't call this a documentary. It resonates like a student movie. This one star is for the music, because Nirvana was awesome.

After viewing "Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck," you may find yourself hesitant to refer to its titular rock icon as the Godfather of Grunge, the Voice of the '90s, or any other title that might further his status as a figure of generational idolization. Unflinching and uncompromising in its unyielding determination to unveil the hidden psychology of Kurt Cobain, gone is the tepid characteristic of most rockumentaries that continue worship and ignore humanity. I suspect that it might come as an overwhelming shock to Cobain's biggest admirers; you won't be much hearing about MTV success, critical acclaim, the untouchable gauze of his influence. You will, instead, live through the interludes of his emotionally tumultuous childhood, his drug-addicted, oft miserable journey into fame, and his clamorous marriage to the self-obsessed Courtney Love. Directed by Brett Morgen with unorthodox enterprise, "Montage of Heck" utilizes the documentary staple that is the one-on-one interview (featuring appearances from Krist Novoselic, Love, his parents, his stepmother, and his pre-fame girlfriend), but is much more reliant on found-footage, rare pre-recorded monologues by Cobain himself, and heterodox animation that both illustrates situations not caught on camera and brings the latter's drawings and writings to life. You really feel as though you standing next to the man himself, consuming his neuroses, understanding of but never able to help heal his most personal demons.  Such idealization has swept the sidelines of Cobain's persona that it makes me like "Montage of Heck" all the more. I've always been a fan of the era defining music of Nirvana, but there hasn't been a second of my enjoyment during which I haven't been wary of his still infatuated circle of fans, who irritatingly romanticize every single detail of his life, who hate Courtney more than they hate Yoko, who act like he was a saint when he was, in fact, a damaged human who needed to be viewed as one but never necessarily was. Because "Montage of Heck" is so disinterested in broadening the girth of "Rolling Stone" level materialism, the effect is remarkable - we thought we had him mostly figured out. Not so. Anyone with an eye for pop culture knows of his lengthy heroin use and his longtime battles with depression, but the film gives us an inside look into these facts with haunting truth. Home videos depict Kurt and Courtney's frightening marriage, characterized within a crumbling apartment, with antics thoroughly drug-fueled; Morgen's spotlight on Cobain's private journals portray him as a man in touch with himself but also as a man ultra-sensitive to criticism, to success, to his emotions. "Montage of Heck" sheds more light onto what destroyed Cobain, not what audiences perceive his psyche as, and it's tenacious. You won't find a better documentary this year, perhaps only rivaled by "Amy," who similarly took an immensely talented musician's tragedy and made it into an unromanticized vision. Cobain's biggest fans will be left broken, his sporadic ones, such as me, shaken. "Montage of Heck" is extraordinary.

Here we discover a more human side to the man, his wife and his accomplices in the band. We realize that he was only a kid who came from nowhere, got propelled to the highest summits and got crashed and burned by fame without truly understanding what was happening. Weather you like the music or not, the documentary gives a new interpretation of a popular phenomenon that shook the 90's. Immensely researched and superbly edited, the film is a lesson on documentary film making. Fresh, modern, thoughtful and respectful, it finally humanize a myth and brings it back to a more human scale.... Maybe that's all it needed after all, simplicity, respect and love.

As a kid that grew up in the 90's and worshiped grunge retroactively, Kurt Cobain was a personal hero of mine. "Nevermind," "In Utero," and Nirvana's MTV Unplugged show were classic albums to me: they helped shape my musical upbringing. Brett Morgen's "Montage of Heck" is the best representation of Cobain's life that I have yet to see in any form, be it film or book. "Montage of Heck" is largely so good because it uses so much unused footage from Cobain's childhood and his years of fame. For those scenes that weren't filmed, Morgen utilizes the private diaries of the Nirvana front man and in some cases, he even creates cartoons to re-enact events from those diaries. The soundtrack is just as original: he finds broken down demos of classic Nirvana songs, like "All Apologies" and "About a Girl" and incorporates them beautifully. Scenes of Nirvana performing, of Kurt at home with Courtney and Frances Bean, are truly heartbreaking and, above all, human. Kurt Cobain was a flawed man, unable to deal with the fame he gained virtually overnight. "Montage of Heck" beautifully captures the life of one of music's greatest heroes and I'd be surprised if we don't see this film again when January rolls around.

The fact of the matter is, the people who absolutely hate this film either #1: do not like Kurt Cobain and/or Nirvana or #2: are super fans who want Kurt exalted and not humanized and think they know him best because they identified with him or listened to his music. After watching the film and learning of the developmental issues he had starting when he was a toddler, my personal opinion is that he suffered from mental illness; his mother even mentions that the pediatrician told them they were in for trouble after looking into his eyes with a flashlight (I suspect something to the effect of Aspergers, Autism, severe ADHD, clinical depression) although they never expand on what the doctor's diagnosis was, except that his mother was to give him prescription pills that seemed to worsen the condition. Keep in mind, he was a child of the 60's/70's when mental illness was more taboo and certain conditions had not even been discovered yet, so essentially he was labeled as being an over active or "bad" kid when in actuality, he needed and would likely have benefitted from professional help. This I feel sets the tone for the remainder of the film and sheds light into his eventual and tragic demise. It is clear that the longer his condition went untreated, the more exacerbated his behaviors became (violent dreams, journal entries and drawings), leading him to self-medicate with pot and eventually heroin to fight the demons inside - making it obvious that he wasn't just some druggie to be accepted by the "cool" kids, but that it was the only way he knew how to silence his erratic brain activity. The film shows the many sides of Kurt Cobain: charismatic/funny, insecure, self-loathing, loving, disturbed, artistic, sad, hopeful - proving that there were many intricate components to this rock legend who I feel is too often simplified. I think the most disheartening aspect of the movie is you get the sense through his journal entries that he really did want to be a better person, especially once Francis was born; but alas, his inner demons got the best of him. Ultimately, my husband and I left the theater with a greater appreciation of Kurt Cobain and his tumultuous life. In the end, it doesn't matter what any of us think - Francis Cobain stated that this was the movie she was hoping for, and since she is his daughter, I would say rightfully that if she is accepting of the film, then we should be too.

Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck (2015) has the distinction of being the first Kurt Cobain documentary made with the cooperation of the Cobain family (Cobain's daughter, widow, and mother). This film stays away from any of the conspiracies or conjecture swirling around Cobain's suicide. To convey the narrative and prevent any one talking head's point of view to dominate the narrative the filmmakers rely largely on home videos, Kurt's own artwork, notebooks, and journals some dating back to Kurt Cobain's early childhood. Lucky for the film maker it appears Kurt Cobain's mother kept all his childhood art projects. This choice gives you some very personal insight into the doc's subject and allows the director/writer Brett Morgen to not make a traditional biography or an over glorified Behind the Music. The film has a sense of honesty and candor that is exemplified in the scenes taken from home videos of Kurt Cobain and his wife bathing their baby daughter. Mr. Morgen doesn't fill in the blanks of Kurt's life with theory and postulation or give rationalizations or explanations for actions. The films real trick is making you feel satisfied you've been told a complete narrative despite the shadowy ambiguous areas. Morgen's access to archived material and use of journals and artwork is ingenious because it allows the deceased to tell us his own tale posthumously through his artistic expression. The film uses several interview clips where Kurt himself tells the viewer, "The art speaks for itself". Noticeably missing from the documentary is former Nirvana drummer Dave Grohl. Mr. Grohl's absence is ever more conspicuous due to his former band mate Krist Novoselic compelling and charismatic interview intercut and used throughout the film. The movie doesn't attempt to fill in the blanks nor should it. The film is less about the facts and figures of Cobain's life but how those events made him feel and how it influenced his art. Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck (2015) is a fantastic example of a narrative that shows rather than tells through amazing access to Kurt Cobain's art work and archives. If you're in the mood for a documentary with interesting storytelling choices and devices or a music fan you'll enjoy this film.

Many Kurt Cobain documentaries have come and gone, and some might argue that there is nothing more to be said about the grunge godfather that took his own life when the walls seemed to be closing in. But I beg to differ. Kurt the musician has been demystified time and time again, but Kurt the human being has never seemed so tangible as he does in this masterful documentary. With never-before-seen footage and access to the people closest to him such as Courtney Love and his parents, this film paints an empathetic portrait of a man who would define Generation X without ever wanting to. Super 8 home footage of him and his beau's tomfooleries at home really serve to paint him as the doting husband and loving father that he really was (trying to be). Some of the most effective scenes are animated recreations of certain pivotal moments where Kurt himself serves as narrator. They reallt don't make docs like this anymore, and it would be a disservice to the lasting impact of his music and singular voice if you didn't give this doc a chance! Masterpiece.

A very in-depth look into Cobain's life - including ~25min of childhood & teenage years, that you don't hear about too often. It's a hard story to tell, since we all know there's no happy ending and it really is Nirvana's music that truly defines him. I guess it's just a little annoying that there's not more interview footage of him (due to his stubbornness/anxiety) and we have to rely on Love's home videos, which are intimate, but don't really show either of them in the best light (except when she's trying to get as many shots of her breasts in as possible, trying to show how 'hot' she once was). Because of Love's control of the film, there's unfortunately only Grohl (& Smear) in archive footage, which is a major shame, since he would no doubt have plenty to say on the matter, and probably more articulately than Novoselic. Good, but nothing too new or shocking.

An uncomfortably close look at the private life of Kurt Cobain, short-term rock superstar and unwilling voice of a disgruntled generation. In the decades since his untimely suicide, Cobain's become an almost mythical figure, which isn't to say he was anything less at the height of his mid-90s popularity. To that end, it can be useful to ground his legacy in this way: intimate home video footage shows him unguarded behind closed doors, but also captures his steady state of mental decay. Where there's a gap in his video history between childhood (and it's heartbreaking to watch this happy little boy, knowing what tragedies his life held in store) and early adulthood, journal entries, artwork and beautiful animated segments keep the narrative moving. Clearly he was hanging on by a thread for longer than most could manage, pushed into a pit of despair by a bleak combination of abandonment, physical frailty, intense media scrutiny and constant, desperate drug abuse. It's not the Cobain many of us might want to see, or to believe in, but it feels so close to the truth that I could almost feel his breath on me. As an extreme close-up on one of my era's biggest names it's significant, with a killer soundtrack of course, and unexpectedly real. It frequently feels invasive, though, especially in the interviews with his parents (his stepmother's continuous, awkward smile is particularly unnerving) and I'm not sure I'm totally okay with the way it made me feel. Powerful in many good, and many bad, ways.

Not a Nirvana fan, I watched this film with the hope to find an "authentic" portrait of Kurt Cobain (this is the first documentary officially endorsed by Cobain's estate) 21 years after his suicide (this film should have been released last year to commemorate two full decades since "the World lost Kurt"). Disappointingly, I only got exactly what the title is (!) - a "montage of heck" about Kurt's life from a peaceful childhood to an "adolescence-in-crisis", to an early burst in fame, and finally a chaotic family life that was more "Sid and Nancy" than "John and Yoko". The montage was made with beautiful 16mm sequences of a bright, handsome, energetic, and deeply sensitive Kurt, and plenty of psychedelic illustration of his painful scrawls and symbolic drawings. Indeed the film has a huge amount of original footage and first-hand information about Kurt, but they were arranged in an "artsy" way that might look like Kurt's style and thought but in fact did not deliver anything about how he really lived his life, how he really thought about people, about love (well, there were touching moments when Kurt shared about his love for Courtney and Frances, but such precious "moments of truth" were again cut in piece by confusing illustration and out-of-tone soundtrack), how people did did love Kurt, did care for Kurt. Actually, the interview sequences of Krist about Kurt are surprising good - honest, touching - that shows how humble Krist is, how much he understands and cares for Kurt, and through his words, how sensitive Kurt always was, and how naive and unprepared Kurt (and Nirvana) was facing fame. But such honest sequences of interview were often under-used and, when used, misplaced (the interview of Kurt's mother did not look real, and did not provide much information about Kurt's thoughts or characteristics when he was still a child under her care). The soundtrack is not really outstanding either with a confusing arrangement throughout the film that did not provide much "emotional boost" when necessary for the audience. Maybe I am not a Nirvana fan, but Kurt's songs like "Smell Like Teen Spirit", "Come As Your Are", or "Where Did You Sleep Last Night" are really a part of my meager "music knowledge" to the point that I will probably sing them to my child as ... lullaby. That is why I really want a good cinematic portrait of Kurt, but sadly enough, this is not such portrait, what a waste of original footage.

Su adicci�n a las drogas, problemas cr�nicos de salud y mentales y su relaci�n inestable con Courtney Love, fueron todos factores que lo llevaron a su inevitable suicidio.Montage of Heck repasa todo lo que fue su vida, pero desde su punto de vista. Recursos como sus diarios y animaciones son utilizados para hacernos sentir que estamos viendo un flashback de su vida a trav�s de sus ojos. Intense, personal, and with its heavy use of home video footage and journal entries, probably the closest we can get to being inside the mind of Cobain; The movie also manages to remain unbiased in its portrayal, focusing on the person he was, for better or worse.

Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck (2015) Dir. Brett MorgenWith unprecedented access to the Cobain family's archive, director Morgen also gets the blessing from Courtney Love in this documentary about the '90s grunge icon Kurt Cobain. In a variety of styles all sound-tracked by Nirvana's breakthrough garage sound, the film uses family footage, home videos, vox pop interviews and voice recordings to build up a true "montage" rockumentary of the front man as he battles his demons. Beginning with his family background, Kurt is portrayed as an (almost) typical teenager looking for an ideal that his home life cannot give him. Wanting but at the same time resisting the family dynamic around him, the film cleverly uses animation made from his sketchbook drawings and handwritten notebooks to bring the parts of his life, well, to life. Morgen even goes for a Scanner Darkly-style animated film to showcase Kurt's attempts at escapism from the mundane suburban life. His white trash "friends" he surrounds himself with are set against his first thoughts of suicide after a failed attempt at losing his virginity. These turbulent teenage years living with a variety of family members and friends but never belonging are insightful reminders of the fragile human behind the legend. Unheard songs and reworked versions of his classic, dare I say, hits show the inherent contradiction of the man wanting yet shunning adulation at the same time. Personal ambitions grate against the ugly commercial aspects of the "biz" and it is a comprehensive portrait to the point of obsessive. The film's 132 minute run time may put off the casual viewer but I suspect the film's target audience would be as fanatical as the film's protagonist about his music and how the world influenced / infected him. Taking its name from a cassette recording of a musical collage made by Cobain, his daughter, Frances Bean Cobain, was also a producer on the film and the documentary is brilliantly haphazard. With the feel of an unfinished scrap book, the film solidifies Cobain as the generation's voice of dissatisfaction. Like Cobain, the movie has a unique take on the world but tries a little too hard to be alternative and its bloated run time has an air of the excessive adulation Cobain wrote about and often shunned from. An ongoing stomach illness is brought to the forefront as the cause of pain but Cobain admits it could have been the aching inspiration of his genius. Sadly, his subsequent suicide resulted in a happiness he forever denied himself and also denied his closest family, friends and fans. A denial til the end.8/10 Midlands Movies Mike

Whether you like his music or not, this documentary is a fascinating look into a man who, for the most part, was a troubled genius. The super 8 films and home videos of Kurt and Courtney are what make the film standout. I thought the interviews were insightful, but didn't need the dramatic lighting and camera angles. It is less about his music than it is trying to figure out what was going through his mind and made him what he was.Grade: B+

It's been 21 years since the untimely death of rock legend Kurt Cobain. Since then, there have been countless biographies and documentaries looking into his life and music, but there has never been one deeply as intimate as Montage of Heck. Brett Morgan dives not just into the music of Nirvana, but into what made his music so impactful. With access to the entirety of Cobain's archives, it's no doubt the territory Morgan was entering would be earth shattering: Unheard tracks from before Nirvana had formed, tape recordings of Cobain's astonishing ideals and disturbing confessions, and some heartfelt home videos of his childhood. To go even further, he animated his journal entries to really bring to life his drawings and poems, giving us a glimpse at how agitated and alone Kurt felt. Truly this is no average documentary. Morgan goes the extra mile to give you the feeling you're actually getting to know Cobain for the first time. He reminds us that he was more than just the "voice of a generation". He was a person like you and me. He struggled and he triumphed. He had a longing heart to be part of a loving family. He hated rejection, and he thrived on attention. His fame was driven by his pain, all the while leading him to his self-destruction. Brett Morgan's Montage of Heck tells the hard story of Kurt Cobain's life with integrity and care. It's electrifying, raw, heartrending, honest, and keeps his fire from never fading away.

It's hard to separate my feelings about this person from my thoughts on the movie. While I didn't know him, I and many more like me always felt a closeness and kinship beyond what one normally senses for an artist whose work one finds appealing. The movie's great. It finds a lot of its artistry through an expression and interpretation of Kurt's own artistry; it feels connected to him that way, as if he's helping tell the story. It seems to cover pretty familiar territory as a rock movie in the first half (I was mostly reminded of The Wall), but eventually (and successfully) detours into what feel like uncharted waters. It seems an empathetic and yet unflinching look at Kurt. The movie lays him bare, but seems to love him, too; and for that it's beautiful. And sad. There's a lot that gets said here, particularly in the interviews; but there's a lot that's still unsaid and that one can easily read between the lines. Not an easy film to watch, but done with care and compassion, and worthy of its subject.
if I didn't grow up watch a ton of Nirvana bootlegs, I would have enjoyed it more. But it felt like a repeat dazzled with some home video and animation.
Absolutely brilliant and moving, #kurtcobain:montageofheck is a uniquely artistic and fitting documentary of one of the most iconic artists of a generation.
Well done doc....sad to see and say that sometimes you know some people are not long for this world but he left one hell of a legacy.
Experience Kurt Like Never Before...Its Dark, Its Intense, Its Overwhelming..Its Evrythn Which a Rock Fanatic Can Evr Wish For....The whole experience is so unreal..
Excelente documental ! A�n no puedo creer que la diva pedorra de Dave Grohl no diera ninguna entrevista en el mismo :/
The documentary gives a good insight to Kurt Cobain's life, but not every single aspect of that is particularly interesting.
Informative, and unique, Montage of Heck shows a more intimate, yet disturbing side of Cobain's short life of fame.
Whether or not you're a Nirvana fan, I highly highly recommend Montage of Heck. Its absolutely riveting from start to finish.

Something tells me the next few months are going to get interesting as far as how the media picks up on the official story of Cobain's death. 'Montage of Heck' is going to debut on HBO, May 4th, 2015. 'Soaked In Bleach', which reveals the events behind Kurt Cobain's death as seen through the eyes of Tom Grant, will debut in some international countries (Norway, Sweden, Germany, Japan, Australia and Finland) soon, and a US date might be announced within the next month.I recently saw 'Montage of Heck', and will offer my review of the film below. Warning: This contains spoilers.To be honest, I like some parts of this movie and hate other parts of it. I'm going to try to include some of the better moments, because who wants to constantly talk about depression? It was obvious that the director was trying to build the narrative that Kurt was suicidal from his formative years to his later years, but I like how it was Kurt telling parts of his story in the beginning and not Courtney, even though what was shown in the film was picked to build the narrative. I also appreciate how much work went into some of the animation and the editing. One of my favorite songs 'Territorial Pissings' is played to start off, and I thought it was well done; the way they showed clips and photos from the culture of the 50's and 60's as the song fades away and it's just Kurt's vocal track. These were the highlights of the movie to me, the new Nirvana music videos we were able to experience.The movie then goes into the beginning of Kurt's life in Aberdeen, with Kurt's mom, Wendy O'Connor telling the story. I'm not going to do a play-by-play of the movie, but it is amazing there are so many home movies of Kurt as a child. He was definitely loved as a little kid before his sister was born. Anyway, the most interesting thing from this part of the movie is the interview with Kurt's dad and his stepmother. This is the first time I've ever seen them besides the early pictures of Don with Kurt as a kid. What struck me was how uncomfortable they looked talking about how they handled the divorce situation. Kurt had a hard time getting along with his family after the divorce. His mom didn't seem to like some of the habits that Kurt inherited from his dad (Hint: when she says, "That's very Don Cobain.") I never really bought into the idea that Kurt slept under the bridge he wrote about in 'Something In The Way', I thought he may have spent some time there (not sleep there), but I believe the broken home scenario was more real than I initially thought.It then starts getting into some uncomfortable material, with the story of Kurt wanting to lose his virginity before he died and his first attempt at suicide. It can be debated whether this should have been included, but at least it was Kurt's voice telling this (his story should come from him). The one thing that is interesting is how Kurt recorded everything; even a telephone conversation between him and Buzz Osborne (The Melvins). It kind of reminds me of 'The Devil and Daniel Johnston', where Daniel Johnston recorded his own movies and audio.Then, my favorite part of the movie starts where they get into him actually playing music. You know... the music. The journal entries were turned into animation, showing the different band names that Kurt went through before deciding on Nirvana. I liked how this was done, and it didn't always have that somber tone. It has clips of Kurt trying to write 'Breed' and 'Been A Son'. The interview with Kurt's girlfriend, Tracy, was not too bad (but nothing really new), and there was a funny moment of Kurt playing his guitar when the phone rings; Kurt picks up the phone and tells whoever is on the other end that Tracy is at work, and he takes a message. I don't know why I found this so funny, it was like Kurt was writing a song one minute, and then he had chores to do.I thought they should have spent more time on this era in his life, as he was laying the foundation for Nirvana. I agree with Alice Wheeler, that the film never focused on the scene in Olympia; other artist's that helped support his creativity. This is the time he wrote most of his songs; even some that are on 'In Utero.' They try to talk about Kurt's heroin use at this time, again to build the narrative for later in the film, but even in Kurt's own journal entries, he says he tried heroin 5 to 10 times during this period. Not exactly a hardcore addict, so of course, Tracy didn't know about it. It's not exactly revealing that he tried heroin because of his stomach problem.Then, we get to the interview with Wendy O'Connor that didn't entirely make sense. She tells a story of when Kurt showed up at her place (looking like Don Cobain) with the master tape of his new album (Nevermind). She tells Kurt to play it and turn it up, up, up... and then she says she was scared. Really? Wouldn't the first reaction be, "Hey Kurt, this is really good." If Geffen Records knew it was going to be such a big hit then why did they only print 50,000 copies of the first run of 'Nevermind'? She should have been working at Geffen. Her story of telling Kurt, "You are not prepared for this," seems a little too contrived.The film then goes into Kurt's rise to fame by showing an airplane taking off. Even though this is a movie focused on Kurt and not Nirvana, I felt they should have mentioned how Dave Grohl joined the band through Buzz Osborne. Kurt was excited when Dave joined the band, so even though the film is just about Kurt (not Nirvana), it is still a part of Kurt's life. We then get the somber rendition of 'Smells Like Teen Spirit'. The film does this a lot, with having a less serious moment, followed by a somber moment. According to the director, it's because that's the way Kurt was. Hmmm, ok, whatever... nevermind.Then, we get to Courtney. I'm not going to talk trash. Actually, there was a fun Courtney moment, where she was dancing on the side of the stage to Nirvana's music. It was actually a decent moment to show (if she was actually dancing to Nirvana and not some other band; remember context is important).Another funny moment was when they started showing the home videos between Kurt and Courtney. Courtney says to Kurt, "How come everyone thinks you're the good one and I'm the bad one?" Kurt replies, "Because I know how to use my illusion"; which is a reference to Axl Rose. It shows how quick and funny Kurt actually was at times, even though the rest of these home videos become really annoying. They seem obsessed with what is said about them in the tabloids.I haven't seen anyone talk about the comment "I paid for this" yet. Courtney asks Kurt, "Where are you going?" as he starts to walk away. Kurt jokes, "I'm going to MY end of the room... I paid for this." Yes, you did Kurt. I didn't think about it at first, but I think it is interesting that the director included this, and the disclaimer during the end credits, kind of says something about how the director was a little conflicted.Did anyone else notice that someone must have been filming Kurt and Courtney in the bathroom? It wasn't a selfie shot like some others. I'm guessing it was Eric Erlandson, as he was shown filming in the clips just before this scene. When Courtney drops her towel and kind of smiles at the camera while Kurt's back is turned, that kind of says it all.Anyway, back to the music. I really liked when they showed Nirvana playing 'Drain You' at a sound check which was played before their show at the Paramount Theatre in Seattle on October 31st, 1991. If I remember correctly, Kurt's guitar was out of tune when they played it live during the show, so it was good to hear the intro (in tune) during the sound check. I also liked that they showed Kurt cracking jokes at the 'MTV Unplugged' taping, even though they then turned it into a somber moment. This wasn't the last show Kurt played, the band toured for another 4 months after this.Some of the Courtney interviews will make you cringe; especially when she talks about how she thought about cheating in London, but never did. And the comment where she says Kurt told her, "I'm going to get to 3 million dollars and then I'm going to become a junkie." Really? That seems really specific. Why wasn't it 2 million dollars or 3 1/2 million dollars? 3 million dollars? Ok. Whatever.Some Nirvana fans know that 'Where Did You Sleep Last Night' was covered by Kurt before Courtney even came into the picture. So the idea that he played that song just because of Courtney's infidelity, doesn't really jive. Even if he did pick that song because of Courtney, then her story of the first time she thought about cheating was in London of 1994, doesn't make sense with why Kurt chose to play the song in November of 1993.It would be nice if we could get a confirmation (since this is the 'definitive Cobain documentary') on the number of rohypnols that Kurt actually ingested during the Rome overdose? Medical documents? Anything? Courtney has changed the number on this. First it was 50, now it's 67. Supposedly, Kurt was a psychic and knew that Courtney was 'thinking about cheating'. So he got so upset that she was 'thinking about cheating on him' that he overdosed on rohypnols (the date rape drug).All you have to do is listen to Nirvana's concert on February 24th, 1994 (four days after Kurt's birthday) to know that the person she was 'thinking' about cheating on him with was Billy Corgan. During that show in Milan, Kurt and Krist were cracking jokes. Krist would say, "I'm Billy Pumpkin." Kurt would reply, "No you're not! You're Meat Loaf!" That's not exactly the depressed state the film attempts to make you believe about how Kurt couldn't cope with her 'thinking about cheating.'I don't want to talk about Kurt's heroin use, because I wasn't there. The clip where he is holding Frances while she is getting a haircut isn't really all that comfortable to watch. Brett Morgen (the director) stated in an interview that Krist Novoselic and Kurt's sister did not want this shown in the movie, while Frances (Kurt's daughter) did. It does beg the question, if he couldn't function on a normal hit of heroin, how does he take a massive hit of heroin, cap the needles, put them away and operate a gun?Some of the journal entries don't always fit the timeline. They show an entry that repeats "Kill Yourself" followed by "Rape is good". For those who don't know, one of Kurt's notebooks was stolen around 1992. The song 'Do Re Mi' and the journal entry above can be interpreted as Kurt not wanting his privacy raped. The line 'Kill Yourself' could be meant to say to anyone reading this kill yourself because you think raping my privacy is good. And that is the only problem with the movie; it sometimes takes things out of context to fit its narrative.Also, the film never talks about how Kurt got his stomach problem diagnosed properly. In 1993, Kurt's stomach problem was diagnosed as a pinch nerve. He had talked about this in interviews that he was so relieved that this problem didn't bother him anymore. Since the movie talked about him being sick and trying heroin because of the stomach problem, then there should have been some insight into what caused the problem.The film ends as you think it would, you know, Kurt couldn't cope so he committed suicide. It does end abruptly leaving room for discussion. Then, Nirvana's cover of 'Ain't It A Shame' starts playing. Yes, it is a shame.Final thoughts:'Montage of Heck' has some good moments, and some things that make me scratch my head and test my logic. The music still sounds great, 25 years later, in any format. There is footage and audio that I've never heard before, and I am glad to hear anything new all these years later. I wish they would have done 2 separate films; one that is a film focused just on Nirvana and Kurt's music (all of those audio tapes of him writing songs could have made its own film). The other film could have been the story of a man destined to commit suicide. The humiliation and shame Kurt experienced only made him try to rise above each time throughout the film, and it will be debated whether or not he was planning to die or rise above Courtney's wandering eye.I will say this, though; there are hints that the director was conflicted in how he told this story. If you watch closely, you will find one thing sometimes contradicts the other. So is this the 'definitive Cobain documentary' that has been advertised? In some ways, yes and in some ways, no. It's the only documentary that obtained the rights to use Kurt's music and art. It's dark, but when you peel away the somber undertones that will make any person look like they were destined to destroy themselves and try to remember the better moments; it's pretty good.

By no means a traditional doc telling the backstory of Grunge Icon Kurt Cobain but more of an artistic retelling through the huge archieves of previously unseen home videos, sketches, music and new interviews with key people close to Kurt. In some ways it is almost like the Cobain Journals that came out last decade was put to screen in a lot of ways. Not hugely relevetory outside of the lead up to the Rome suicide attempt and Courtney's potential trigger for it, along with the painful; intimacy for the homevideos of Kurt, Courtney and Frances while Kurt was severely high. Very painful to watch. Full marks for being unflinching and the use of some staggering animation throughout the proceedings although seemed to be a tad long. However would have been cool to see some more intimate videos with Kurt and the band outside of one token jam session when they were first starting out but otherwise fairly intriguing.

Sure it doesn't delve into the music side of things as much as it arguably should. But both as a glimpse into the headspace of a tortured artist and as an avant garde narrative, it is a stunningly effective journey.
awesome on so many levels..
I don't review movies much anymore, but this is enough to possibly revert me back to homeostasis without even being fiction.

This is a window into the mind of one of the all-time great rock visionaries. Rather than having a strict plot, it mostly consists of montages of Cobain's art and home movies.
