Brett Morgen (The Kid Stays In The Picture) uses archival footage, notes, drawings, and unseen home videos to bring to light the life and times of Kurt Cobain, the legendary singer/guitarist for the band Nirvana. We get a very intimate glimpse of the beloved musician from his early years all the way up to 1994, when he tragically took his own life at the age of 27. Having seen other documentaries produced on Nirvana and Cobain, I couldn't help feel that they were more idol-worship and spent less time focusing on the troubled life this man had. So, I was surprised and in some cases shocked with how much of his past they discussed. The use of home video footage to show how drug addiction drastically changed his mental and physical state, it was extremely upsetting to see. I grew up listening to these guys! Kurt was a gifted songwriter and musician. So, to get this level of intimacy and detail about his life. To see the events that made him the way he was. It was impressive that someone was able to put a documentary together that felt less like a love letter and more of a character study. I think it is the only real way you can effectively tell this story and they did it very well. On top of all this! Morgen utilized the incredible animation skills of Stefan Nadelman and Hisko Hulsing, to bring to life drawings done by Kurt. As well as, brilliantly bringing to life major events in the young Cobain's life. Which included his family troubles and his musical beginnings. The only issue I really had with the film was the exclusion of Dave Grohl, whose omission was a choice the director made. I felt it would have given the film a little more. But, ultimately I had no major issues with this documentary. It is very well done! The animated sequences alone make this worth your time. Even if you don't like Kurt Cobain! This is a great character study that doesn't pull any punches as it focuses on the events that both made and ultimately destroyed an extremely talented musician.

Ganda nung animated short story at kung paano ginamit yung mga art work, journlas home video etc. mula kay Kurt. Over all medyo magulo at di comfortable panuorin pero siguro ganun naman kasi yung buhay ng subject.

Brett Morgen writes and directs Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck. The film focuses on the life of Kurt Cobain, and does not venture much into the aspects of Nirvana. The film starts off with footage of his childhood as well as interviews from his family. Its clear that his troubled teen years led to much of the angst present in his music. The film somewhat loses the documentary sense and becomes more of a myriad of imagery, and splicing together montages to construct what may have been going though his life. Footage of his wife Love also ensues, and the focus of the film really shifts to that relationship. Those looking for more a music based documentary will be disappointed as this film really only mentions the albums being made in passing. The film does not attempt at all to look at the impact or legacy of his life past his death. Overall Montage of Heck is worth watching for any Kurt Cobain or Nirvana fan, but I felt the film had a bit more fluff with the imagery and montage aspects as an artistic film rather than a documentary.

I think this documentary is a success overall, but it has a few flaws. Kurt died in 1994, and in a lot of ways the sound of his gunshot is still ringing. There were a couple of entire generations (myself included) that were deeply affected by Kurt's suicide, and perhaps we still have some repressed feelings about it. This film brought back a lot of emotions from the time, and it made me think about how quickly we seemingly "got over it" as a society.It made me feel like I had some buried-away, bad memories about losing or being betrayed by a loved one, and that I've tried to forget through the years more than I'd like to admit. And I wasn't even the biggest Nirvana fan at the time, but I still remember that awful feeling, like horrible, confused betrayal and a feeling like we we're collectively abandoned. So it made me wonder about the lasting effects that his life and his suicide may have actually had on the public these past 20 years, its probably more than we can quantify. It was nice to see video of Kurt as a young, happy kid. It was almost cathartic. I wish the movie had focused more, however, on this happy, positive side of Kurt. As the film progressed, it seemed to get darker and darker. I know that parallels his actual life, and obviously things got very dark at the end. But there were times in this film that I thought the writers were exploiting this, and unfairly portraying Kurt only as an out of control, suicide obsessed maniac, without focusing at all on his art, or any other positive thing he did.Even happier scenes with his wife and daughter were riddled with shots of scrawled lyrics in notebooks about suicide and mental illness, most of which were obviously taken out of context. There is one set of lyrics that say "kill yourself. kill yourself..." over and over. But at the bottom of the screen the next verse is out of focus. It says "rape is good. rape is good..." These are clearly satirical lyrics. It's like the director won't let Kurt have those happy memories, and has made the choice not to let us have those happy feelings either. All in all, this movie has shed some light on some really intense emotions that I think some of us have effectively hidden away through the years, but it didn't do much to resolve those feelings, and in some ways it made them feel worse. It was successful, however, in documenting his life, and I think it has helped to restart the conversation. The film was well constructed, chock full of rare, unseen footage and some insightful interviews. Maybe in the long run it can help heal some of the wounds that some of us perhaps never properly dealt with.
AMAZINGGGGGG MOVIE!!!!

As with every other kid who grew up in the 90s, Nirvana was instrumental in molding my musical tastes. Whether he liked it or not, Kurt Cobain came to represent the voice of a generation, and nearly no stone of his mythic rise to fame has been left unturned in the 20+ years since his tragic suicide. The new documentary, and first officially supported by his family, Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck, takes a little bit of a different angle by attempting to pear inside the headspace of the mythic figure instead of merely covering all of Nirvana's milestones. Part of it is very much a conventional life-to-death biography, featuring scattered interviews of family and a few close friends (although the fact Dave Grohl's interview apparently couldn't be completed in time to make the cut is a glaring loss), but the other part is much more abstract, mishmashes from Cobain's journal and home videos along with animations of his artwork, often set to Nirvana songs or home demos. It's a haunting look at a man who clearly experienced a lot of personal hurt and turmoil in his brief time here on Earth, and a stark reminder of the horrors of heroin. Whether or not it allows us to understand Cobain better, well, that's anybody's guess.

For the most part it was good. There was plenty of video footage and some audio clips that have never been scene before (officially and unofficially). The first half of the documentary had home movies of all the Cobain's and it puts out a good vibe with plenty of info on Kurt throughout his early life and his teens. About half way through though, around "Nevermind"'s release things sort of start breaking down and becomes less informative and more of showing off Kurt's home videos of him, Courtney and Frances. It gets rather boring and kinda weird and then the whole documentary ends abruptly. Maybe its suppose to represent the title but I would have preferred it to be a little more traditional. Overall its still a good documentary but its not the best one on one of the most brilliant musicians to ever live.
Really good. Really dark. Must watch again soon.

Even though I wasn't completely objective due to my extremely distain for Courtney as well as a newfound annoyance with Brett Morgan (he just seems a bit too pompous, exhibiting an extremely righteous glee about MOH), I tried my best to watch without too many preconceived notions.I've read a plethora of glowing reviews, hailing Montage of Heck as sensitive, deeply moving and genius. I disagree.Montage of Heck was strangely disturbing to me, in a violating kind of way for the lack of better words.The weird thing is that I cannot pinpoint why I was so fucking uncomfortable during most of the movie. Was it Courtney's feeble attempt to deflect attention away from her issues, thus making Kurt the scapegoat in some of the footage, or maybe it was the films general voyeuristic tendency?I don't know why the movie left such a bad taste in my mouth, something just seemed wrong. I do however support Alice Wheelers reaction/post about Montage of Heck and share very similar feelings about this so called "honest" travesty.
This was engrossing and well done artistically, but left a lot to be desired in the way of information. Still recommended. Eerie, to see the man behind the music, and the reality behind lyrics.

A journey into Kurt Cobain's life, often misunderstood and complicated since his younger days which influenced his music. A lot of personal unseen videos on his life which sometimes sad to watch especially when he was heavily living with drugs. A bit disappointed Dave Grohl wasnt interviewed tho.

Totally blown away by KURT COBAIN: MONTAGE OF HECK. The best doc I have seen in years and that rare film whose style and format is totally in keeping with the spirit of its subject. You feel immersed. You understand. You see what's important in all new ways. A staggering achievement!
Not enough.....never enough,,,,,,,

A captivating examination of the paradox that was the voice of Generation X, Kurt Cobain. From his early childhood in Aberdeen to his death, Brett Morgen weaves a tapestry of film footage, notebook scribblings, recordings, and stories together to narrate the journey through Kurt's 27 years on planet Earth. I liked it, but I am biased as I was a freshman in high school the year Nevermind was released. The imagery is dark, not for the faint of heart. I had no idea how busy Kurt Cobain's mind was producing the images and lyrics he so urgently had to express to the rest of us. Sad story, but helps us better understand this tortured soul.
A frenetic, fascinating sprint through Cobain's life that never gets lost in its maker's clearly abiding love for the man and his music. An uncensored look at what made -- and unmade -- Cobain.

A superb documentary offering new insight in to the life of the enigmatic legend that is Kurt Cobain. With never before seen footage this is both touching and disturbing and reminds us all of the loss the world gained when Kurt Cobain sadly took his own life - RIP.

If you're familiar with the mythology of Kurt Cobain and Nirvana, the epic rise out of nowhere-Washington to the biggest rock God of them all, then this is a splendid film which greatly humanizes Kurt and Courtney and checks in with Krist Novoselic in his balding middle-age. The endless home movies from Kurt's childhood up to his last days show sides of him that were not well known before and add something different to the way he and those close to him have been portrayed up till now. Likewise the quotes and illustrations from his journal fill in this artful portrait of the sarcastic lead singer of Nirvana.
Ugh, what a mess. Such a disappointment.

It is always interesting to discover new aspects of Kurt's life. This documentary sheds some light into his family history and it sort of makes sense that a child who was neglected/abandoned by his mother and father would grow up unhappy and angry. His mother seemed to hate Kurt's father more than love her son. It was interesting to see his ex-girlfriend talk about him, it looks like she supported him a lot and helped him develop and deepen his creativity. I certainly don't think that Courtney Love is evil, she grew up with very similar problems herself and she still seems like a very troubled individual. I think that she really loved Kurt. However, she and her daughter initiated and produced this documentary and it seems to me that they cared more about protecting Courtney's legacy rather that Kurt's - Was there any need for the "We love you Courtney" incident? But still, it's interesting to see things through her perspective. All biographies are pieces of a puzzle that you can put together with other input in your mind and form your own opinion of a personality you are interested in. I read that their daughter Frances Bean wanted to debunk her father's myth and the subject of a glorified rock n' roll suicide with this documentary and to some extent she achieves it. However I do think that Kurt was a very complicated person and so much more than a sad junky who couldn't get laid, which is basically what you take away from this documentary. I, like I am sure all Nirvana fans, was surprised and disappointed not to see Dave Grohl in this documentary. I did some research and read that he was interviewed for it, but very late and there was no time for his interviews to be in. I hope that they will manage to get them in at a later cut, or as bonus features. But even with no Dave being interviewed, couldn't the director at least mention him and how/when he got into Kurt's life, instead of treating him like a film extra? Apparently the director said that Dave wasn't so important in an "intimate" documentary about Kurt, but this was one of Kurt's close friends and main artistic collaborators, and that's a very intimate process they went through together. Big miss, very disrespectful to Dave, and it won't help improve Courtney's notoriety, many people will assume it was because of their bad relationship and lawsuits over rights to Nirvana's music. It was nice to see Krist Novoselic talking about Kurt, you can feel the love he had for him. The documentary was very well made and I loved the gradual, fast-paced montages of Kurt's artwork and writing, which give you an idea of his manic creative flow. Also depicting Kurt's zeitgeist helps to better understand him. We miss you, Kurt.
Great Doc! Gives a real insight to his creativity
The most intimate of Cobain documentaries. Brilliantly told through remarkable visual and audio pieces.

Definitely worth checking out if you were into Nirvana or a kid who grew up in the grunge era surrounded by that scene taking over the world (briefly). Well-crafted and engaging from start to finish. It shows a side of most people that we never see, the carnally insecure and flawed side we keep hidden and locked in dark places and behind masks. Even if it can be hard to watch at times, there is certainly value in that exploration.

21 years since we lost this incredible musician. It was interesting to look back on what led to his rise and inevitable fall into extreme degradation. I was unable to appreciate this during the pre-internet age.

Although it offers no new insight into Kurt's troubled mind, the story is told very well especially in the montages of sound and vision. Say what you will about Courtney, but it's clear that he loved both her and the baby without question, and it's still very sad that he's gone from us far too soon

I saw a Facebook post, reviewing this movie, saying "He was a human -- not a god." I never thought Kurt Cobain was a god. I have always respected him, because he was a person who suffered deeply, and he tried to make something with it. Whether it was just to work out his own pain and rage or not, he has now reached multiple generations of troubled kids and at the very least let them know they are not alone (which is the one thing almost all of them believe they are). Someone else has felt this. He, like so many, was trying to find a light in the darkness that wanted to consume him. Unfortunately, and very tragically, that did not happen, but he tried. His music is one of the things he helped to create that has outlived him, and the world is better for him having been here. However short his time here may have been.
Really enjoyed watching the succession of such a talented virtuoso, the tender home videos were precious as hell. Who wrote better songs than this cat?
This... this was very good.
Sterile, disengaged, heartless vanity piece.
The rare interviews and other source material make this a must see for any Nirvana enthusiast.

Access: amazing. Animation: inspired. It's so rare that you get an insight like this into an artist who has had such an impact. Storytelling is equally impressive, up until the very end, when the filmmakers decide to drop the mic on the whole thing and hastily walk out of the cinema. Maybe they thought it was punk rock of them, but it makes their carefully-built story unsatisfying by the end. Must still give it 4 stars, for everything up to this point.
A Must- See !!! This movie will take you for a ride you won't forget !

Montage of Heck does justice to Kurt Cobain in many ways. The movie give's extremely intricate detail from the start of his life leading to his playing on MTV Unplugged. Kurt Cobain was already someone i thought was quite a philosophical and intelligent person, but this movie made me gain a lot more respect for him. This is the one film this year that i believe everyone need's to watch. 9.5/10

Incredibly self-indulgent, but I guess it has to be, right? Seemed a bit long to me. Very fair portrayal, though probably too heavy-handed at some points. Could have used more Dave Grohl. I heard that the director didn't have time-MAKE TIME, dude. He's the most famous/successful out of all of the people who knew Kurt.

Morgen went a little heavy with the surreal montages in lieu of, I don't know, actually information about Cobain and the events leading up to and following his death. This documentary has to about 80% animated collage. If Morgen was just going to stop the night before he died, this only needed to be an hour long maximum ( minus the dancing cartoons ).
Half decent documentary but the music is dreadful and so painfull to listen to, he really couldn't sing. Don't understand why he was so famous
two stars taken away because i hate courtney love and she is clearly pulling the strings on this , controlling the discourse if you will and you don't learn anything new really

An amateur porn would be less intimate that what is shown in this movie. As the documentary itself reveals, Cobain hated being ridiculed, judged for his life rather than for his music, and more generally being exposed, chewed by and eventually sentenced by strangers who were and are morbidly attracted by how he was in his privacy. Despite its positive elements-such as the richness of the materia or the animation parts-I could not help but feeling uneasy for the most part of it, a little ashamed of me partaking in this, commercially-driven, and socially shared act of violation.

As a Nirvana fan, I enjoyed this, but would be lying if I said I wasn't a bit disappointing considering the hype built around this. It's a very profound examination of Cobain as an artist, but aside from home video footage, there is nothing new here that you haven't seen before or don't know about. It also skims over several important parts of Cobain's life and gets a bit repetitive at over 2 hours. I also really disliked the way the director chose to end it as well. An entertaining watch if you're a Nirvana fan, but it's all just a bit too familiar.

The documentary about the most enigmatic rock musician of the 90s is a rich tapestry to his pathos. Built around videos, notebook writings, and artwork that Cobain himself made over the years (along with some unexpected use of rotoscoping) Montage of Heck attempts to get to the root of Cobain's affliction, and does it in a rather unorthodox way. Fans of Nirvana will enjoy seeing the previously unreleased material, and others will admire the documentary's craft, and unconventional design. Like Nirvana's music, Motage of Heck is beautiful, disturbing, and fun all at the same time.
Drugs and addiction in general suck!! Not a Nirvana fan but still this was a very enjoyable documentary, perfect for the hard-core Nirvana fans.

As far as the unseen and unheard footage, interviews, and sound clips go, this is about as personal as we can get into his life. It does a decent enough job for an overall documentary I suppose. However it glazes over many subjects mostly due to the fact that Courtney Love and Cobain's family had the control of what was shown and detailed. You can tell that it is completely biased in that regard. The created animations were superbly meshed well with Kurt's art and sound clips. Definitely worth watching, even if you're not a fan of Kurt or Nirvana. I'm looking forward to Soaked In Bleach which will cover more concerning the conspiracies and usually overlooked details about the end of his life.
I cannot wait to see this....
A hard-hitting, visually arresting new angle of the complex, contradicting personality of Kurt Cobain.
I am a Nirvana fan, my wife hates Nirvana. We both loved Montage of Heck.
Makes creative and enlightening use of rich archival material. Should be seen on a big screen with the volume turned up. God, I miss troubled-genius rockstars.

First off I'd like to point out I am and always will be a Nirvana fan. If you are a fan its a must see. If you're not a fan, you should watch it and look at him as someone who had it all and struggled with the fame. The film (produced by his daughter Frances Bean and Widowed wife Courtney Love) show how Kurt made something of himself after years of negation from family and school mates. The story is heart breaking but develops into a story of success, but its not all glam and party all the time. "He wanted to make $3,000,000 and quit to become a junkie." as his widowed wife mentioned in the film. Although it shows more private videos of Kurt and how he was with family (which had a few funny moments) You also meet his parents and sister that have NEVER been in the public eye. Not going to go into detail about everything in the film because its something you should watch yourself if any interest at all. But a few things bothered me, such as no mention of their wedding in Hawaii and how Kris wasn't there, or when Kurt lived with Dave Grohl (No Dave was not in the movie either due to timing of the filming and Dave filming Sonic Highways). The movie kinda leaned toward how Kurt was a tortured soul and made you believe he would of committed suicide, It made Courtney Love seem like such a level headed person who didn't really have much control of Kurt and how they were a team when I've heard stories of how she controlled him. Another part was when Courtney was telling the Rome story, yea you make your own call of judgement on that one if she was lying or not. Me? I wanted to yell out bullshit but i held my tongue. I understand now why some people who knew Kurt thought this movie was bullshit and Courtney had to be part of the editing process of this film when the director Brett Morgen continues to claiming he and the editor were the only ones who were in the room editing this film.Final word. May 4th.. HBO and movie theaters North America will be playing this film. I say go and enjoy the soundtrack along with the visuals.

A must for any fan of the late Kurt Cobain. A look inside his life and career featuring plenty of rare and unreleased footage. After coming out in limited release, it will go straight to HBO. He's been dead for 20 years and yet he still has a large cult of fans and followers.

Montage of Heck was absolutely incredible. Director Brett Morgen truly succeeded in breathing new life into the icon, by shedding light on the story of man behind the music and myth. The documentary was humanized through the integration of Kurt's writings and recordings, as well as by the gritty animation of the frontman's paintings, drawings, sculptures, and sketches. This is a must see, and not just for devout Nirvana / Cobain fans.

In a feature too long for my tasting, Brett Morgan cleverly knits together the remains of what was a short but fruitful rockstar career. The film never fails to entertain, but lacks the ability to tell a new story. The most important additions are the Love-Cobain couple's home-videos, which leave an image of the artist that should be remembered. But that is not an addition we can thank the makers for. What we can thank them for however, is the bril animation sequences.

So its good that a lot of the key people in his life give interviews and you get some real insights into the man. There seems to be a lot of great footage, the shots of him as a kid and him with his kid are heart breaking. However by the end the arty montages get a bit tedious and they could have spent a lot more time and detail elsewhere.
The one and only Kurt Cobain film. Now I wish I could just unsee all the other previous Kurt Cobain films. Esp. Gus Van Sant's version is horrible in retrospect.

A ridiculous memento mori of an overhyped musician, who did his best to kill the music that made him famous. The only reason why this film exists, is because he made the smart career move of dying before his 15 minutes were up.
